case_name: Oriental Mercantile Agency v. Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Madras

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment dated July 7, 1970 of Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1971. Appeal by special leave. from the judgment and order dated July 7, 1970 of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969.

facts.text: High Court quashed award dated May 25, 1968 of Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment dated July 7, 1970 of a Division Bench of the High Court at Madras in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969, quashing an award dated May 25, 1968 of the first respondent, the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Madras.

facts.text: In 1961, appellants Oriental Mercantile Agency retrenched six workmen resulting in industrial dispute referred to Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961 the appellants, Oriental Mercantile Agency, re- trenched six of their workmen resulting in an industrial dispute which was referred by the Government of Madras to the Labour Court for adjudication.

facts.text: Question referred to Labour Court: whether retrenchment of six workmen justified and relief entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to the Labour Court was whether the number-employment of the six workmen was justified and what relief they were entitled to.

facts.text: Labour Court award dated June 14, 1963 by Shri S. Abdul Azeez held retrenchment justified, no relief.

anchor.surface_text: By its award dated June 14, 1963 the Labour Court  Shri S. Abdul Azeez  held that the number-employment of the workmen was justified and therefore they were number entitled to any relief.

facts.text: Workmen filed Writ Petition No. 209 of 1964 in Madras High Court under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: Against the award of the Labour Court the workmen filed writ petition No. 209 of 1964 in the Madras High Court, under Article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Venkatadri J. judgment dated February 20, 1967 set aside Labour Court award, retrenchment unjustified, remitted for fresh disposal.

anchor.surface_text: Setting aside the award, Venkatadri J. held by his judgment dated February 20, 1967 that the number-employment of workmen was unjustified, that the intention of the management was to weed out those whom it did number want and that the reasons given by the management for terminating the services of the workmen were fanciful.

facts.text: Appellants filed Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 against Venkatadri J. judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed writ appeal No. 113 of 1967 against the judgment of the learned judge.

facts.text: Division Bench Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J. dismissed Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 in limine on April 4, 1967 without hearing workmen.

anchor.surface_text: That appeal came for hearing before Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J., who by their order dated April 4, 1967 dismissed the appeal in limine, with the following observations ... Notice of the appeal was number issued to the workmen and the order extracted above was passed without hearing them.

facts.text: Workmen moved CMP No. 7125 of 1967 for clarification of Venkatadri J. judgment dated February 20, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: While the matter. was pending before the Labour Court, the workmen moved a petition in the High Court, CMP No. 7125 of 1967, seeking clarification of the judgment dated February 20, 1967 of Venkatadri J.

facts.text: Venkatadri J. clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967: remitted only for reliefs, retrenchment unjustified finding binding.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated June 26, 1967 the learned Judge clarified his earlier judgment by saying that he had remitted the matter to the Labour Court only for the purpose of determining what reliefs companyld be given to the employees who were retrenched from service...

facts.text: Management filed CMP No. 8579 of 1967 for review of Division Bench order dated April 4, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the management filed CMP No. 8579 of 1967 for review of the order dated April 4, 1967 passed by the Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967.

facts.text: Division Bench dismissed review application on July 31, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated July 31, 1967 the Division Bench companysisting of the same learned Judges,  Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J.  , dismissed the review application.

facts.text: Labour Court Shri S. Gonsalves award dated May 25, 1968 held retrenchment justified relying on appellate observations.

anchor.surface_text: By its award dated May 25, 1968 the Labour Court took the view that ,,it is settled law that the powers of a High Court while hearing a writ petition under Article 226 of, the Constitution of India are limited only to remitting a case to the lower Court for fresh disposal in its entirety...

facts.text: Workmen filed Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969 against 1968 award.

anchor.surface_text: Against that award the workmen filed a writ petition  No. 122 of 1969 , which was referred by a learned Single Judge  Ismail J.  to a Division Bench.

facts.text: Division Bench Veeraswami C.J. and Gokulkrishnan J. judgment July 7, 1970 quashed 1968 award, directed only reliefs.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment of July 7, 1970 the Division Bench  Veeraswami C.J. and Gokulkrishnan J.  quashed the award of the Labour Court and remitted the matter to it with a direction that it ought number to go into the merits or the propriety of the retrenchment, but dispose of the matter only in respect of the proper relief or reliefs to be given to the petitioners.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1971 filed by special leave by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1971. Appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside order dated April 4, 1967 of Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 for violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the order dated April 4, 1967, passed by Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J. in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967, as being in violation of the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 of Venkatadri J.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 passed by Venkatadri J. in C.M.P. No. 7125 of 1967 as, in face of the appellate order, howsoever wrong, the learned Judge had numberjurisdiction to issue a clarification...

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside award dated May 25, 1968 of Labour Court Shri B. Gonsalves.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the award dated May 25, 1968 of the Labour Court  Shri B. Gonsalves , as that award companyld number have been given without the High Court companysidering the legality of the judgment of Ven- katadri J.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside judgment dated July 7, 1970 in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the judgment of the High Court dated July 7, 1970 in Writ Petition No. 122 of. 1969 which was filed against the award of Shri Gonsalves must also be set aside.

facts.text: Supreme Court directs revival of Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 for disposal on merits after notice to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Since it is necessary in the interests of justice that the legality of Venkatadri J.s judgment must be determined, we direct that Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 shall be revived and that the High Court do dispose of that appeal on merits after issuing numberice thereof to the respondents-the workmen.

facts.text: Retrenchment of six workmen by Oriental Mercantile Agency in 1961 was disputed as unjustified by High Court single judge.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961 the appellants, Oriental Mercantile Agency, re- trenched six of their workmen ... Setting aside the award, Venkatadri J. held ... that the number-employment of workmen was unjustified...
Appeal by special leave.
under Article 226 of the Constitution.

issues.text: the correctness of this judgment [of Division Bench dated July 7, 1970]

anchor.surface_text: The correctness of this judgment is challenged in this appeal by special leave. Obviously, the Labour Court found itself in a quandary. While setting aside its award,

issues.text: Whether the order dated April 4, 1967 passed by Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J. in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 is sustainable as being in violation of the principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: in total violation of the principles of natural justice. We are also clear that, apart from this, the Division Bench was in error in taking the view that Venkatadri J. had not expressed a final conclusion on the questions arising before him.

issues.text: Whether Venkatadri J. had expressed a final conclusion on the questions arising before him

anchor.surface_text: the Division Bench was in error in taking the view that Venkatadri J. had not expressed a final conclusion on the questions arising before him. It is unfortunate that the learned Judge remitted the matter to the Labour Court for fresh disposal,

issues.text: Whether the learned Judge had jurisdiction to issue a clarification which was inconsistent with the view taken by the appellate court

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge had no jurisdiction to issue a clarification which was inconsistent with the view taken by the appellate court. The appellate order was binding on the learned Judge. We set aside the award dated May 25, 1968 of the Labour Court

issues.text: Whether the powers of a High Court while hearing a writ petition under Article 226 are limited only to remitting a case for fresh disposal in its entirety with observations being obiter dicta

anchor.surface_text: powers of a High Court while hearing a writ petition under Article 226 of, the Constitution of India are limited only to remitting a case to the lower Court for fresh disposal in its entirety and that consequently any observations made by it while ordering such remission are mainly obiter dicta,

issues.text: Whether the legality of Venkatadri J.'s judgment dated February 20, 1967 must be determined

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court has not tested in appeal the validity of Venkatadri J.s judgment, it is necessary to direct that to be done. That can be done only if, along with the judgment under appeal, certain other orders and judgments are set aside.

arguments.claim: Division Bench order dated April 4, 1967 in violation of natural justice as passed without hearing workmen

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that the learned Judges who dismissed Writ Appeal 113 of 1967 were, with respect, in error in making observations which were calculated to prejudice the workmen without giving them an opportunity of being heard... start from scratch, in total violation of the principles of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Division Bench erred in holding Venkatadri J. did not express final conclusion

arguments.claim: Venkatadri J. should have avoided clarificatory order in interests of judicial discipline after appellate construction

holdings.text: The order dated April 4, 1967 passed by Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J. in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 is set aside as being in violation of the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the order dated April 4, 1967, passed by Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J. in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967, as being in violation of the principles of natural justice. That order cannot bind the workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal in limine without issuing notice or hearing the workmen prejudiced their rights, violating audi alteram partem.

holdings.text: The Division Bench was in error in taking the view that Venkatadri J. had not expressed a final conclusion on the questions arising before him.

anchor.surface_text: the Division Bench was in error in taking the view that Venkatadri J. had not expressed a final conclusion on the questions arising before him. It is unfortunate that the learned Judge remitted the matter to the Labour Court for fresh disposal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Venkatadri J. recorded unequivocal finding that retrenchment unjustified, though remitted for fresh disposal.

holdings.text: Venkatadri J. had no jurisdiction to issue the clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 inconsistent with the appellate order, which was binding on him.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge had no jurisdiction to issue a clarification which was inconsistent with the view taken by the appellate court. The appellate order was binding on the learned Judge. We set aside the clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 passed by Venkatadri J.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate construction of judgment binds single judge; clarification undermined appellate order without setting it aside.

holdings.text: The clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 passed by Venkatadri J. in C.M.P. No. 7125 of 1967 is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 passed by Venkatadri J. in C.M.P. No. 7125 of 1967 as, in face of the appellate order, howsoever wrong, the learned Judge had no jurisdiction to issue a clarification...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issued despite binding appellate order; single judge cannot contradict appellate bench.

holdings.text: The award dated May 25, 1968 of the Labour Court Shri B. Gonsalves is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We set aside the award dated May 25, 1968 of the Labour Court Shri B. Gonsalves , as that award could not have been given without the High Court considering the legality of the judgment of Venkatadri J.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Labour Court could not readjudicate merits without appellate court testing validity of Venkatadri J.'s judgment.

holdings.text: The judgment dated July 7, 1970 of the High Court in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969 is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the judgment of the High Court dated July 7, 1970 in Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969 which was filed against the award of Shri Gonsalves must also be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dependent on invalid prior orders; legality of Venkatadri J.'s judgment remains untested in appeal.

holdings.text: Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 shall be revived and disposed of on merits by the High Court after issuing notice to the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Since it is necessary in the interests of justice that the legality of Venkatadri J.s judgment must be determined, we direct that Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 shall be revived and that the High Court do dispose of that appeal on merits after issuing notice thereof to the respondents-the workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legality of Venkatadri J.'s judgment on retrenchment merits not tested in appeal; requires determination for justice.

holdings.text: Venkatadri J. should have avoided making the clarificatory order in the interests of judicial discipline.

anchor.surface_text: He should also have avoided, in the interests of judicial discipline, the making of a clarificatory order. The Division Bench, in the appeal against his judgment, had placed a certain construction on that judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate construction binds; clarification disrupts hierarchy.
